UPDATE: 12-4-2015

It would appear they fixed the issue with the loading screen taking half a millenia to take you to the game, but it's still a steaming, festering pile of excrement on the face of the sandbox genre. The game itself feels like I'm playing something that's still in alpha rather than something that's a full release. The audio is janky and widely inconsistent when you're at a stand still as opposed to when you're walking. The mining worlds are extremely empty and small, and just the entire experience is horrible. It's like trying to swallow peanut butter with an allergy to the stuff.

I don't understand why someone would knowingly release a game that's this unfinished and expect people to fork over their hard-earned cash for it through microtransactions. It's like putting whipped cream on a pile of dog poo.

WARNING: The positive means try the game, NOT that i liked it. Bring a friend.

Hi. So i decided to try this game, with my friend.

my friend gave up in an hour

i stuck around for the second hour.

it was a bad mistake.

Pros:
I like the music

Unique idea i suppose....

My friend claims hes gonna hang himself
you need THREE people to enter a dungeon. Hell i had a hard time trying to find ONE person.
In gods name is this stupid furnace?!?!?! it makes random items?!?! The hell?!?!?!

It took me and hour and a half to find the tutorial. I kid not. The game didnt guide me at all. i was so lost
Why are there no trees? just floaty leaves? the floaty leaves give wood but still... WHen was the last server wipe???
Only one ore in the game and it gives you ALL the metals

No fall damage?!?!?! At all??? I feel like this game was made for 3 year olds who cant handle sharp corners
Where in gods name do i get a weapon? i really wanted to try a dungeon.

After looking at this game enough, i litterally tried to find a history on the devoloper to see if he commited suicide because the thought scared me, oddly enough a rich russian by the same name (Shumkov Dmitriy) commited suicide a month after this game was made.... I hope this was a different guy and it was just a odd coincidence...

The game has promise i give it that...Maybe just maybe there could be a way to enjoy this game.... I REALLY wanna say it was a good game but i cant. It has promise... I give it that much,... At least i stuck around to learn the basics of everything unlike those 0.1 Hours guys.

In the end, the game is fun for about a hour if you invite a close friend and just play to have a laugh at its stupidity. I cant reccommend seriosl playing the game though, as serious game play is very boring. and will end in like zero results

I say, try the game, just try it. You probably wont like it but its worth the laugh with close friends

reviewText:
I can't find anything good to say about this game. Honest. Screenshots look okay, but the game's hardly polished and the interface is terrible (no shift-clicking, crafting/furnace window is not intuitive).

Downfalls:
- Tools have no durability, and the pickaxe tool seems to work on everything, regardless of the material (dirt, stone, wood).
- You also cannot jump and place blocks directly underneath you, so I hope you like digging stairways.
- Trying to build a bridge out from a hill, the game won't let you place blocks unless you hang off the block and place while jumping. (At least in Minecraft you could sneak off a ledge and slap a block on.)
- Physics on this just feel wrong: jumping from block to block you may sometimes miss or just jump up faster than you anticipated.
- The textures are atrocious and hurt my eyes after a while. With no outline of the box you are targeting, things can get disorienting, especially in caves.

Also, many maps are ravaged: trees gone (floating bushes), obscene words spelled out in text, abandoned dirt huts, etc. It just feels like the land has been pillaged for someone's personal cache.

TL;DR - Crappy F2P voxel game with item mall to get you to spend money. Take your hard-earned cash and go buy Minecraft instead. It is a much more satisfying experience.

reviewText:
I couldn't not give this a look, what with how people have been tearing this apart in the reviews section. Unlike RotMG, where I had expectations going in due to prior experience, and was hoping that the skeptic reviews were just hyperbole,

this I knew was a descent into madness at minute one.

After I made my character, the game unceremoneously throws me into my home plot, a 15x15x15 cube populated with only grass and dirt. After 20 seconds of immediate shock, laughing and thinking this was just the tutorial map, that good spirit immediately died when I realized the game's not joking; no matter where I went, I always had to come back to that worthless patch of grass.

Before I went adventuring, the first thing I did was attempt to jump off the side. Sadly, I discovered I wouldn't be escaping this game so easily, as every time I'd be jolted back. No size of jump can possibly kill you, either, to my dismay when I built a hole to the bottom of my plot and then leaped into it. After that, I decided to do 'quests' the game had in store for me. I start off on the first quest....and quickly lose interest, opting instead to dig out my entire plot into an empty husk; rather, emptier than it was. But as I was, maybe, 1/50th of the way done, I realized I didn't want the game to think I was putting in more effort than it took to make it, and just gave up. Then again, I did clock 2-1/2 hours on this, so you can't say I didn't spend more time than the developers spent on QA.

The second lie, with a trip to the shop, is that you won't be making the 'house of your dreams.' No, that would require creativity, something this game would like to discourage as much as possible! Instead, you PURCHASE actual houses for, roughly, $30. Ah yes, this game is far from free; It's loaded with what I now like to call 'macrotransactions,' cluttering every corner of it. Want a blueprint for a table? money, please. Want seeds to grow in your garden? Money, please. Want a noose and a chair to end the suffering? WHAT SUFFERING? YOU'RE HAVING FUN, RIGHT? GIVE US MORE MONEY. To a very minute credit, there's a normal currency you can earn off the quests, but it won't buy you much, and the economy is so ♥♥♥♥ed, you'll never earn another coin off whoever may still play this.

After dealing with the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥y involving the shop, I decided to go on my first real trek, thus finally beginning the grand adventures of HELPME. No shock to anyone, the first thing you ever see when entering public instances is a shop where you can buy all you like but sell sweet ♥♥♥♥ all; opposite that, a bulletin board with advertisements for overpriced ♥♥♥♥ you can make with zero effort. You'll learn quickly that all the realms you enter are just as empty and barren as your homestead: the best you'll be able to find in terms of value would likely be crystals, which're rare, and a couple attempts with the RNG-fueled smelter later, I had no idea what to do with. So my wandering a barren land yielded me more ♥♥♥♥ing dirt, a handful of rocks, and some coal. I guess fun is also in the shop as well, I wonder how much I have to pay for fun?

I'd also touch up on dungeons, but I could never enter one! The community is barren, to the surprise of no one; I only saw one other person logged in at the same time as me, and dungeons required 3 people, in some sort of desperate requirement to drum up more players; I guess you can tell how well that worked?

After strip-mining an entire server of all its leaves in a desperate search for planks, since this game has a problem with servers being empty of critical resources due to the fact they never regenerate (ergo no wood,) I made some useless furniture, built a useless well, planted some useless seeds I bought from the useless shop, and then, just as I was experimenting, almost certain I was onto something with the smelter...the game chunked me into a loading screen...then promptly crashed. No better excuse to stop playing, I guess!

In short, this 'game' is the highlight of the worst of free-to-play; it strips itself down to the barest minimum, shoving everything behind a paywall. Its existence is solely as a ♥♥♥♥ing cash grab; a milking of people's yearn for a Minecraft fix they can get free, but it's never that simple. I'm glad nobody plays this; hell, I think I might just have spent more time playing this than anyone, maybe even the developers of this! Because it's obvious, after one look at this abomination, the best place for it is a recycle bin.

reviewText:
If you have played Minecraft, Trove, or Creativerse before, you will find out that Genesis Online is much worse than all these 3 games. The difference between those 3 games I mentioned and Genesis, is the distance between clouds and mud.

Minecraft, pay to play, with thousands MODs and many third-party launchers. You can manage your villages, fight monsters, or mod your game and join Pokemon battles. Minecraft offers the original mining, building and survival experience.

Creativerse, it used to be pay to play in early access, and now it's free-to-play. Absolutely not pay-to-win. Currently cannot be modded, but it has better graphics than Minecraft. I couldn't not give this a look, what with how people have been tearing this apart in the reviews section. Unlike RotMG, where I had expectations going in due to prior experience, and was hoping that the skeptic reviews were just hyperbole,

this I knew was a descent into madness at minute one.

After I made my character, the game unceremoneously throws me into my home plot, a 15x15x15 cube populated with only grass and dirt. After 20 seconds of immediate shock, laughing and thinking this was just the tutorial map, that good spirit immediately died when I realized the game's not joking; no matter where I went, I always had to come back to that worthless patch of grass.

Before I went adventuring, the first thing I did was attempt to jump off the side. Sadly, I discovered I wouldn't be escaping this game so easily, as every time I'd be jolted back. No size of jump can possibly kill you, either, to my dismay when I built a hole to the bottom of my plot and then leaped into it. After that, I decided to do 'quests' the game had in store for me. I start off on the first quest....and quickly lose interest, opting instead to dig out my entire plot into an empty husk; rather, emptier than it was. But as I was, maybe, 1/50th of the way done, I realized I didn't want the game to think I was putting in more effort than it took to make it, and just gave up. Then again, I did clock 2-1/2 hours on this, so you can't say I didn't spend more time than the developers spent on QA.

The second lie, with a trip to the shop, is that you won't be making the 'house of your dreams.' No, that would require creativity, something this game would like to discourage as much as possible! Instead, you PURCHASE actual houses for, roughly, $30. Ah yes, this game is far from free; It's loaded with what I now like to call 'macrotransactions,' cluttering every corner of it. Want a blueprint for a table? money, please. Want seeds to grow in your garden? Money, please. Want a noose and a chair to end the suffering? WHAT SUFFERING? YOU'RE HAVING FUN, RIGHT? GIVE US MORE MONEY. To a very minute credit, there's a normal currency you can earn off the quests, but it won't buy you much, and the economy is so ♥♥♥♥ed, you'll never earn another coin off whoever may still play this.

After dealing with the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥y involving the shop, I decided to go on my first real trek, thus finally beginning the grand adventures of HELPME. No shock to anyone, the first thing you ever see when entering public instances is a shop where you can buy all you like but sell sweet ♥♥♥♥ all; opposite that, a bulletin board with advertisements for overpriced ♥♥♥♥ you can make with zero effort. You'll learn quickly that all the realms you enter are just as empty and barren as your homestead: the best you'll be able to find in terms of value would likely be crystals, which're rare, and a couple attempts with the RNG-fueled smelter later, I had no idea what to do with. So my wandering a barren land yielded me more ♥♥♥♥ing dirt, a handful of rocks, and some coal. I guess fun is also in the shop as well, I wonder how much I have to pay for fun?

I'd also touch up on dungeons, but I could never enter one! The community is barren, to the surprise of no one; I only saw one other person logged in at the same time as me, and dungeons required 3 people, in some sort of desperate requirement to drum up more players; I guess you can tell how well that worked?

After strip-mining an entire server of all its leaves in a desperate search for planks, since this game has a problem with servers being empty of critical resources due to the fact they never regenerate (ergo no wood,) I made some useless furniture, built a useless well, planted some useless seeds I bought from the useless shop, and then, just as I was experimenting, almost certain I was onto something with the smelter...the game chunked me into a loading screen...then promptly crashed. No better excuse to stop playing, I guess!

In short, this 'game' is the highlight of the worst of free-to-play; it strips itself down to the barest minimum, shoving everything behind a paywall. Its existence is solely as a ♥♥♥♥ing cash grab; a milking of people's yearn for a Minecraft fix they can get free, but it's never that simple. I'm glad nobody plays this; hell, I think I might just have spent more time playing this than anyone, maybe even the developers of this! Because it's obvious, after one look at this abomination, the best place for it is a recycle bin.

Minecraft is a sandbox construction game created by Mojang AB founder Markus Persson, and inspired by the Infiniminer, Dwarf Fortress and Dungeon Keeper games. Gameplay involves players interacting with the game world by placing and breaking various types of blocks in a three-dimensional environment. In this environment, players can build creative structures, creations, and artwork on multiplayer servers and singleplayer worlds across multiple game modes.

Minecraft is available to all players for €19.95 (US$26.95, £17.32). When purchased, singleplayer and multiplayer game modes can be played using the downloadable stand-alone launcher. The official demo is free, but has a time limit. Minecraft development started around May 10, 2009, and pre-orders for the full game started being accepted on June 13, 2009. Minecraft's official release date was November 18, 2011. On September 20, 2014, Minecraft for the computer became the best-selling PC game of all time. On December 31, 2015, Minecraft for the computer reached 22 million sales.

On August 16, 2011, Minecraft: Pocket Edition was released for the Sony Xperia Play gaming smartphone. After its exclusivity with Sony expired, it was released for Android devices on October 7, 2011, and iOS devices on November 17, 2011 for US$6.99. On April 2, 2014, Minecraft was released for the Amazon Fire TV. It contains all the same features as the Pocket Edition as well as support for the Fire TV's controller. On December 10, 2014, Minecraft: Pocket Edition was released for Windows Phone 8.1. On January 10, 2015, Minecraft: Pocket Edition reached 30 million sales.

On May 9, 2012, Minecraft was released for the Xbox 360 on Xbox Live Arcade for US$20, where it subsequently broke every previous sales record.

On February 11, 2013, Minecraft: Pi Edition was released for the Raspberry Pi. The Pi Edition was intended as an educational tool for novice programmers and users are encouraged to open and change the game's code using its API. There were never any subsequent updates and the edition is now officially discontinued.

On December 17, 2013, Minecraft was released for the PlayStation 3 on the PlayStation Store for US$19.99. The release was almost identical to the Xbox 360 Edition and was developed in tandem with the Xbox 360 Edition from then on.

On June 26, 2014, the Xbox 360 & PlayStation 3 editions' sales passed the number of sales for the PC edition of Minecraft, leaving the Minecraft series having sold more than 72 million copies world-wide and becoming the third best-selling video game of all time.

Minecraft was released for the PlayStation 4 on September 4, 2014, the Xbox One on September 5, 2014 and the PlayStation Vita on October 14, 2014.

On September 15, 2014, Mojang AB and all of its assets (including Minecraft) were purchased by Microsoft for US$2.5 billion. On July 29, 2015, Minecraft was released for the universal Windows 10 platform as an adaptation of the Pocket Edition.

On December 17, 2015, the Wii U Edition was released.
